text: Essentially when it attacks traumatize target player.
Gotta say wizards has done a great job spreading the CMC of Dinosaurs out across a solid range

Someone clearly put a little brain power into that thought process. I was honestly expecting a blogatog comment/response to the effect of: "why do all dinosaurs cost 5 mana or more, it really takes away the potential to play them in anything but the most casual settings"

"Dinosaurs are most know for their terrifying size. We wanted them to feel large and did this through their mana costs and p/t. Having small dinosaurs would have lessened that impact"

Sorcery

Deals 3 damage to target player or creature. 

3RR: Return Double Volley from the gy to your hand only if you attacked with a creature this turn.
3RR seems excessive.
But there were certainly small Dino's, so while I understand that line of thinking it seems very self-limiting.
Honestly scooze isn't even that good in edh
It's strong elsewhere for sure but in commander I'd rather have a Relic 99% of the time outside a deck abusing counters or something
I completely disagree about scooter in EDH. That has won me several games by keeping me alive long enough to come back from several attacks.
Scooze...Damn You autocorrect!
It's a better fit if you have a graveyard strategy. Relic also leaves you open after one use. I'd prefer ooze if I had the ability to play it.
Also the spot removal aspect keeps gy decks in check while also giving them a beater to worry about.
That relic one use is probably in response to an end of game event though
Possibly...don't get me wrong, Relic is fantastic but saying scooze isn't that good in EDH isn't correct.
If people are leaving creatures around long enough to do that much work then ever creature is a bomb
Even when I ran it in Mimeoplasm counters it was at best useful. Which is fine, but I've heard a lot of really high praise for it that doesn't feel deserved. To each his own though
Sometimes you just don't get your removal...no one just leaves it around but I certain protect it if it makes sense.
For sure. Maybe it's a play style thing too. I'd rather know I can delete an entire yard consistently vs run Ooze that may have more potential upside but may also whiff
Naturally depends on the deck but your one time may also whiff since you get the one shot.
Some people like the higher risk/reward
Pretty hard to miss with a relic or spell bomb
Not really, especially if they know it's there or coming.
Vs the stealth attack of an ooze?
Not at all, but if seeing it prevents them from playing something that too has merit.
consistent attack of ooze
And scooze can go pow-pow.
If I cast a relic successfully odds are pretty high I can empty yards
I may also not want my own gy popped.
Sure but I'm not realty talking about that
That's like saying but ooze tribal

Not saying you can't use the relic, but that the opponent can play around you using the relic. With the ooze it's harder to play around the ooze since its not gone after one use. For instance they cast animate dead on something, your only response is to clear all yards. With ooze you just target the card they want and continue playing. Relic lets them refill yard to try again, but you don't have a source of yard hate left.

Not really. What I'm saying is they are different versions of gy hate with different upsides and downsides. Both are valid...I was merely taking exception to the claim against scooze being 'good' in EDH. I have always found it so.
That entire argument hinges on your ooze living forever
And on Relic getting the most relevant pieces when popped.
Maybe it's a matter of planning for worst case vs best
If you assume best case most of the time then I get liking ooze I guess
Scooze isn't best case, but that isn't how you see it.
Both are good. Each has different situations you can use them in better. Ooze will almost never stop a [[rise of the dark realms]]

text: Good gy decks know how to force opponents to pop their gy hate like Relic when it impacts them the least.
Bear in mind relic also taps
No, but scooze can remove the worst items from coming back.
It's not Formosa crypt
Tormods
True. The lack of targeting makes it tedious though. You have to focus one deck and hope they don't put more than one card per turn for that to be effective
And yeah a good grace deck may know how to force a crypt but it also won't let you keep an ooze that long. You can't use that argument on one and not the other
Yup but now we're talking the difference between targeted and non-targeted removal. You don't have to limit yourself to just one.
I never said scooze was the best gy removal nor Relic the worst. They serve different purposes and are useful in different situations.
I was arguing against the notion that scooze isn't good in EDH not that it was the best hate available.
And I think ooze is fine, but I don't think it's reliable grave hate to look at as a way to save yourself. It's a body with a nice upside tat might get lucky sometimes and do work
Ok...we can agree to disagree on the "get lucky" aspect of that but otherwise yes we're in agreement.
I still think it's not that good :) I wouldn't run it in a deck on its own if there wasn't added synergy like with atraxa or something. It's super narrow. But if y'all don't agree that's fine
I'm wondering why you think it's super narrow. Is it because it's targeted grave hate vs. a mass graveyard exile?
Yes because being able to surgically exile gy pieces is apparently really narrow and bad in EDH...:smiling_imp:
nothing beats [[Rysorian Badger]] when it comes to gy hate lets be honest with ourselves

I'm mostly kidding, but in a three color deck even without ABUR duals or off-color fetches the 3 fetches/3 shocks/3 painlands throw you well over 100, it's black so Urborg is another 20, etc. You can get to close to 200 just with a mana base

I wasn't sure if I wanted to put Urborg in there. I don't think I have a Cabal Coffers so I only see it being worth if I get Crypt Ghast and Urborg out at the same time. Do you think I should, anyway? For the times I DO get them both?
IMO if you're running black run Urborg. That's easy for me to say because I wound up picking up like half a dozen when they were five a pop in M14 or whenever it was.
But even without Coffers it's just such easy fixing.
That's true. And the deck is dominantly black-colored
I mean, I tossed Chromatic Lantern in there for the same reason
I guess it can occasionally bone you by fixing for someone else or enabling their Coffers when they hadn't found their Urborg yet, but I'm not sure that's a reason to not run it
Are you running the Tainted lands? Those are awesome budgets for a deck that is heavy black.
Tainted lands and Odyssey filters are both really nice even if you aren't on a budget. Tainted are harder in three colors.
Urborg lets you tap Maze of Ith and Glacial Chasm for mana, too, and even lets you tap fetches if you need to
And that can be surprisingly relevant.

It's more elegant design for the enchantments to help activate themselves. This theoretically can give you a spell to cast so you can cast three spells. The green one can find you a creature to help flip itself. The black one reduces your life total so you can flip it. That sort of thing
heads
Unless you hit a land. And you don't get a discount on the cast, so it's a bad draw for a turn (unless it's a land)

Sure. The green one can whiff, too. The black one has risks. My point is just that it's more elegant for it to try and enable itself than to randomly trigger off of damage, which isn't the only thing red is good at
It always feels like they assign the C team to design red stuff

The flip side gives you a land-with-a-repeatable-spell after you've cast all the spells in your hand. That's good for red.

They're neat, and it's good design that they enable themselves in one way or another

Cardboard is the way to go...
Yes, cardboard is superior
I wish I could mix the feel of cardboard in my hands with the prices of digital O.O I'd have so much Magic
But when you live hundreds of miles apart...
Yup, exactly. Literally different coasts
You do what chess players do...mail each other decks and play remote games :wink:
Pffft, negative, Ghost Rider :stuck_out_tongue: Ain't nobody got time for that!
That's weak sauce man...
show some committment
Mental magic over discord!
It's too easy to read the backlogs in slack
I actually like the structure of MTGO. The bugs are the only thing that kills me.
You need to play some 3 dimensional magic...

If the cards never bugged, I'd sing praises of the program, clunky or not. Magic's not a simple game like Hearthstone, I don't see how you can have a "simple" interface without cutting steps or details out. I'm going to be very interested in seeing how similar Arena is to regular paper magic

Actually the visual augmentation already demoed in the Arena footage will help new users. My wife likes the Games Knights coverage because of Josh adding in all the action animations that makes watching and following the game so much more immersive.
Naturally they didn't really demo the stack, but I suspect they're still working that out.
True. I mean, HS got super popular for a reason, visuals are definitely some of those reasons.

In an odd coincidence I was in a pod this last weekend where we had to explain priority and the stack to someone. It'd been awhile since I'd had to do that so I wasn't ready for the almost salty resistance. It naturally had to do with him wanting to cast an instant to kill a creature that my son had just cast.
The really odd part was another guy, who's normally a real douchebag, came over and very calmly confirmed what we were explaining.
Huh. Did new guy settle down after that?
He came to the 'whatever' moment, but it does go towards the complexity of the game that we often shortcut in our understanding. These concepts are very difficult to explain and accept early on.
Agreed. I think understanding the right times to play things in relation to priority and the stack have been the hardest, yet most rewarding lessons I've ever learned in Magic
True. It both helps and doesn't help new players that WotC actively tries to hide the stack from them.
Understanding priority and it's relationship to the stack is very complex and subtle, especially since it changes for different spell types, etc.
Yes...he was of the 'but it's an instant, I can cast that whenever I want!"
We shortcut stack access so much, especially in EDH, that it's easy to overlook how that appears to newer players.
It'd be kind of cool if Wizards designed a 1v1 play mat that had the zones, including a "stack" zone so you can place spells in order, in between the two battlefields
Yeah...but then you'd get folks who put stuff on the stack in the wrong order :wink:
Why does WotC need to design that?
I'm pretty sure such a mat already exists
They don't, but it's their game so it would probably be a nicety.
Wizards endorsing it kind of looks better and more official to new players
It's a PR type thing, at least in my mind
It gets really confusing once you start introducing special or state-based actions or other things that bypass the stack.
No...they just break the game
Well, I mean. Yeah :smile:
So now imagine a whole generation training on MTGO who try to play paper and wind up playing around the electronic bugs in the real world...
Oh...I can't morph that card else it will lead to an infinite loop and my cards will crash...
Yeah, admittedly, they need to work on the bugs. They really need to throw some money at the program to fix it. I'm still not sure if I believe Arena will be a decent replacement
Arena has the advantage of only using recent sets with less rules complexity
It won't be a replacement for any time in the near future. I suspect they will never bring the older formats to it.
Its easy to make a full rules engine if you aren't burdened with the complexity of older cards.
It's like winning a prize at the carnival:

text: Rough list Adanto Vanguard, Duskborne skymarcher, Legion's Landing, Mavren Fein, Bloodcrazed Paladin, Sanctum Seeker
Vicious Conquistador, Vanquisher's Banner, Unclaimed Territory
The lands aren't hard I guess
And I'm sure I won't add all thosse
I do like that paladin.
I'm not sure I'm adding Marven into Edgar. Sure, he's a Vampire, he's on curve, but he only makes one token per combat.
I agree with pretty much the rest of this list, though. Not seeing Vona in the deck?

Making a token a combat is fine. You're going to be swinging most turns anyways.
Sacrifice fodder, Cathars Crusade fodder, Bloodline Keeper comes on-line quicker
No, if I'd run five drop gold vampire it would be Blood Baron

Just adds to the numbers.
Vona isn't great. He's not for a vampire deck unless it's focused more on life gain

Dana's list is also focused on 1/2 drops and making gratuitous tokens very quickly, as I've understood it.

I have a more Aristocrat-build, and Mavren fits perfect for that. Vona doesn't because it doesn't have many life gain synergies.

Vona would fit better with a life gain/drain theme where that payment is more feasible reliably
My two cents on it. I'm not a huge fan of Vona to begin with.
Yep, Vona just doesn't fit what I'm doing
